result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Prosecuting Attorney Jeanette Kara Corbett in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Robert Mckinley Thompson in court and by Attorney Matthew Edward Weil. Counsel is awaiting offer from the State.  Plea hearing scheduled for November 21, 2022 at 09:45 am.
Plea hearing on November 21, 2022 at 09:45 am.

Prosecuting Attorney Jeanette Kara Corbett in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Robert Mckinley Thompson appears via Zoom and by Attorney Matthew Edward Weil.  Defendant did not have a ride to court today.  Court has colloquy with Defendant regarding right to be physically present at today's hearing and accepts consent to use of video conferencing. Counsel is reviewing discovery.  Court directs defendant to appear in person for next hearing.
Plea hearing scheduled for October 5, 2022 at 01:15 pm.
